column1: 父は家族のためにいっしょうけんめい働いている。

column3: N1 か N2 (Prt)  is used to present two alternatives. In the case that the second alternative has a particle, the second か is dropped, as here.

column1: その店、おいしいんでしょ。

column3: ~でしょ is the shortened version of ~でしょう　which with a rising intonation is used to elicit the hearer's confirmation; with a falling intonation indicates conjecture. Women traditionally use でしょう （the polite version of だろう）and in casual conversation it is shortened to でしょ。

column1: このケーキ、おいしいだろう。
column2: This cake is good, isn't it?
column3: ~だろうwith a rising intonation is used to elicit the hearer's confirmation; with a falling intonation indicates conjecture.　Men use だろう, which is the informal of でしょう。In casual conversation the final う　tends to drop.

column1: 明日からもっと早く家を出るようにします。

column3: V-nonpast.plainようにする。 Means: make an effort to~; make an effort so that~; try (one's best) to do ~; try one's best so that~. column3: S１。ところが　S２ where S1=what's expected; S2= what actually occurred.  Means: however; but; nevertheless  ところが is a sentence initial conjunction used when something takes place which is unexpected from the preceding context. NOTE: ところがS2 is an event the speaker CANNOT control (like the sensei not being  there as expected) In the event that something unexpected didn't happen by the speaker's doing でも is the appropriate conjunction (such as, the teacher was there, but speaker changed his mind to meet her at the last second)

column3: N をもとに（して） is a compound particle meaning "based on." Here, して is optional.

column1: これは、私の子供の時の経験をもとにした小説です。

column1: 母と同じで、私もえびのアレルギーがあるので、えびは食べられないんです。

column1: スノーボードはスキーと違って、スティックを使わずにすべります。
column2: Unlike skiing, you slide on a snowboard without using poles.
column3: XはYと違っう／と同じだ/ 似ている X is "the same as"/ ""different from"/ "similar to" Y This form is used when X and Y are in a reciprocal relationship.

column1: 多くの国に違って、日本では２０歳にならないと投票できない。
column2: Unlike most countries, you can't vote in Japan until you turn twenty.
column3: N　と違って means= unlike N;  Different from N; unlike ~

column1: 剣道はとても日本らしいスポーツだと思う。
column2: Kendo is a sport that represents the essence of Japan.
column3: N らしい  means that something/someone is representative of N. and XはNらしい conveys the idea that X has the positive characteristics of N. NOTE: らしい is an i-adjective so the noun-mod and adverbial forms are らしい and らしく respectively.

column1: 田中さんは長い間アメリカに住んでいたので、あまり日本人らしくない。
column2: Ms. Tanaka lived in the US for a logn time, so she isn't like other Japanese people.
column3: 〜らしくない／らしくありません Means: not much like, not typical of ~; not typical~; not X-like.

column1: 今年の夏は寒い日が続いて、全然夏らしくありません。
column2: Summer this year has been cold day after day; it doesn't feel summery at all.
column3: 〜らしくない／らしくありません Means: not much like, not typical of ~; not typical~; not X-like.

column1: 「男らしい」とか「女らしい」という言葉は、あまり好きではありません。誰でも、その人らしく生きればいいのではないでしょうか。

column2: American; historical literary; international general

column1: 京都や奈良は歴史的な建物がたくさんある伝統的な街です。
column2: Kyoto and Nara are traditional towns with many historic buildings.
column3: N+的 the suffix is attached to nouns to make them な-adjectives. When these adj modify nouns, the な is sometimes omitted.

column1: オリンピックをすることに決まってから、その国は国際的になってきた。
column2: After it was decided that it would host the Olympics, that country has become more cosmopolitan.
column3: N+的 the suffix is attached to nouns to make them な-adjectives. When these adj modify nouns, the な is sometimes omitted.

column3: N+的 the suffix is attached to nouns to make them な-adjectives. When these adj modify nouns, the な is sometimes omitted.

column1: 漢字がもっと簡単に覚えられたらいいのになあ。
column2: I wish it were easier to memorize kanji.
column3: S-plain.past (V are typically volitional) らいいのになあ。 is used to express the speaker's wish, which, in this structure, is usually counterfactual. なあ serves to make it more emotive. Verbs, usually volitional, refer to the SPEAKER'S actions. This is a very casual expression.

column1: 寮の部屋がもっと静かだったらいいのに。うるさくて勉強ができない。
column2: I wish the dorm were quieter. It's so noisy that I can't study.
column3: S-plain.past (V are typically volitional) らいいのになあ。 is used to express the speaker's wish, which, in this structure, is usually counterfactual. なあ serves to make it more emotive. Verbs, usually volitional, refer to the SPEAKER'S actions. This is a very casual expression.

column1: 寂しいなあ。恋人ができたらいいのになあ。
column2: I'm so lonely. If only I had a sweetheart…
column3: S-plain.past (V are typically volitional) らいいのになあ。 is used to express the speaker's wish, which, in this structure, is usually counterfactual. なあ serves to make it more emotive. Verbs, usually volitional, refer to the SPEAKER'S actions. This is a very casual expression.

column1: 量は多かったけれど、お腹がすいていたから、ほとんど食べてしまった。
column2: There was a lot of food, but I was hungry, so I ate almost all of it.
column3: ほとんど　V Means "almost all; most of (it, the time, etc.)" It is only used with the amount of something is the issue.

column1: 昨日は疲れていたから、1日中ほとんど寝ていました。
column2: I was tired yesterday, so I slept almost all day long.
column3: ほとんど　V Means "almost all; most of (it, the time, etc.)" It is only used with the amount of something is the issue.

column1: おいしい料理だったが、お腹が痛くてほとんど食べられなかった。
column2: The food was good, but I had a stomachache,so I could barely eat anything.
column3: ほとんど〜ない。 means: hardly (ever); rarely; almost no(thing)

column1: 寝られなくなるので、私はほとんどコーヒーは飲まない。
column2: It keeps me from sleeping, so I almost never drink coffee.
column3: ほとんどの N means Almost all N; most of N

column1: 彼はこの大学の有名人だ。ほとんどの人が彼のことを知っている。
column2: He's famous at his school. Almost everyone knows him.
column3: ほとんどの N means Almost all N; most of N

column1: 今日の試験のほとんどの問題が、宿題と同じだった。

column1: この頃前より日本語が話せるようになってきたような気がします。
column2: Recently, I've felt like I can speak Japanese better than I could before.
column3: ~(ような）気がする Meaning; I feel that~: I have a feeling that ~; have the impression that ~; it seems to me that~  It indicates that the speaker is not certain about something, but has the feeling that it's true. ような can be dropped without changing the meaning.

column1: 先生の説明を聞いて、分かったような気がしたけど、家に帰ってもう一度勉強し直したら、また分からなくなってしまった。
column2: I felt like I understood it when I heard the professor's explanation, but, when I went home and reviewed it, I got lost again.
column3: ~(ような）気がする Meaning; I feel that~: I have a feeling that ~; have the impression that ~; it seems to me that~  It indicates that the speaker is not certain about something, but has the feeling that it's true. ような can be dropped without changing the meaning.

column1: 誰かがドアをノックしたような気がするから、ちょっと見てくれない？
column2: I think someone may have just knocked on the door, so could you go and check?
column3: ~(ような）気がする Meaning; I feel that~: I have a feeling that ~; have the impression that ~; it seems to me that~  It indicates that the speaker is not certain about something, but has the feeling that it's true. ような can be dropped without changing the meaning.

column1: この辺は、あまり安全じゃない気がする。
column2: I get the feeling that this area isn't very safe.
column3: ~(ような）気がする Meaning; I feel that~: I have a feeling that ~; have the impression that ~; it seems to me that~  It indicates that the speaker is not certain about something, but has the feeling that it's true. ような can be dropped without changing the meaning.

column1: 2年生の日本語より3年生の日本語のほうが簡単な気がする。
column2: I feel like third-year Japanese is easier than second-year.
column3: ~(ような）気がする Meaning; I feel that~: I have a feeling that ~; have the impression that ~; it seems to me that~  It indicates that the speaker is not certain about something, but has the feeling that it's true. ような can be dropped without changing the meaning.

column1: これから公園へサッカーをしに行くところです。
column2: I'm just about to go to the park to play soccer.
column3: V-nonpast ところ Means: (when) ~is about to V

column1: 友達の携帯に電話をかけているところにその友達が現れたので、びっくりした。
column2: I was surprised because my friend showed up just as I was calling her on her cell phone.
column3: V−teいるところ Means: (when)~ is V-ing; (while)~is V-ing; (when)~ is in the midst of V-ing ところ indicates a point in time just before, during, or just after an event, the time indicated depends on the preceding verb tense.

column1: ちょうど勉強が終わったところに友達から電話がかかってきた。
column2: My friend called just when I had finished studying.
column3: V−past ところ Means: (after) ~have just V-ed ところ indicates a point in time just before, during, or just after an event, the time indicated depends on the preceding verb tense. When ところに appears the clause is a time clause, as here.

column1: ここからペンギンが水の中で泳いでいるところが見られます。
column2: You can see the penguins swimming underwater from here.
column3: V−teいるところ Means: (when)~ is V-ing; (while)~is V-ing; (when)~ is in the midst of V-ing ところ indicates a point in time just before, during, or just after an event, the time indicated depends on the preceding verb tense.

column1: 子犬が寝ているところを写真に撮った。とてもかわいい写真が撮れた。
column2: I took a picture of the puppy napping. I could take a very cute picture.
column3: V−teいるところ Means: (when)~ is V-ing; (while)~is V-ing; (when)~ is in the midst of V-ing ところ indicates a point in time just before, during, or just after an event, the time indicated depends on the preceding verb tense.

column1: 話すところ
column2: ~is about to talk
column3: V-nonpast ところ Means: (when) ~ is about to V  ところ indicates a point in time just before, during, or just after an event, the time indicated depends on the preceding verb tense.

column1: 食べているところ 考えているところ 電話をかけているところ
column2: (when) ~is eating  (while) ~ is thinking  (when) ~ is in the midst of calling
column3: V−teいるところ Means: (when)~ is V-ing; (while)~is V-ing; (when)~ is in the midst of V-ing ところ indicates a point in time just before, during, or just after an event, the time indicated depends on the preceding verb tense.

column1: ちょうど勉強が終わったところに友達から電話がかかってきた。
column2: Exactly after I had just studied, I got a call from my friend.
column3: V−past ところ Means: (after) ~have just V-ed ところ indicates a point in time just before, during, or just after an event, the time indicated depends on the preceding verb tense. When ところに appears the clause is a time clause, as here.

column1: 試験が終わってから、答えを間違えたことに気がつきました。
column2: After the test was over, I realized I had written the wrong answer.
column3: S　ことに気がつく means: notice (that~); realize that ~  Notice that the presence of こと in a sentence using this grammar may not always be the nominalizer meaning "that." It could be a noun meaning "thing" following the noun-typed usage of this grammar.

column1: なかなか面白いことに気がつきました。
column2: I noticed that there are some pretty interesting things.
column3: N　に気がつく。  Means: notice (that~); realize that ~  Notice that the presence of こと in a sentence using this grammar will not always be the nominalizer meaning "thing." It could be the Sこと form for statements using this grammar.

column1: 家に帰って初めてカバンの中の財布がなくなっていることに気がついた。
column2: It was when I returned home that I first realized that my wallet had disappeared from my bag.
column3: S　ことに気がつく means: notice (that~); realize that ~  Notice that the presence of こと in a sentence using this grammar may not always be the nominalizer meaning "that." It could be a noun meaning "thing" following the noun-typed usage of this grammar.

column1: 引っ越す前は、アパートの前の道がこんなにうるさいことに気がつかなかった。
column2: Before I moved in, I didn't realize that the street in front of the apartment was this noisy.
column3: S　ことに気がつく means: notice (that~); realize that ~  Notice that the presence of こと in a sentence using this grammar may not always be the nominalizer meaning "that." It could be a noun meaning "thing" following the noun-typed usage of this grammar.

column1: 人は失敗して初めて、自分のしたことが間違えっていたことに気がつく。
column2: It's when people fail that they first realize that what they'd done was wrong.
column3: N　に気がつく。  Means: notice (that~); realize that ~  Notice that the presence of こと in a sentence using this grammar will not always be the nominalizer meaning "thing." It could be the Sこと form for statements using this grammar.

column1: 子供達が幸せな人生が送れるようにと願っています。
column2: I hope that the children can be sent a happy life.
column3: S-plain.nonpast ように（と）願う Means: hope that ~ And is used to express the speaker's hope or desire that what is stated in the sentence will become a reality.

column1: 多くの人々が早く世界が平和になるように願っている。
column2: Many people hope that we'll have a peaceful world soon.
column3: S-plain.nonpast ように（と）願う Means: hope that ~ And is used to express the speaker's hope or desire that what is stated in the sentence will become a reality.

column1: 弟が大学の入学試験に合格できるようにと毎日祈っています。
column2: I pray every day that my little brother will pass his university entrance exams.
column3: V.nonpast.plan. ように（と）祈る Means: pray that ~ Used to express the speaker's hope or desire that what is stated in the sentence will become a reality.

column1: 毎年お正月に神社に行って、今年も大きな病気をしないように神社に祈ることにしている。
column2: I make it a habit to go to a shrine every year on New Year's Day and pray to the gods that I'll be able to avoid any major illness during the year.
column3: V.nonpast.plan. ように（と）祈る Means: pray that ~ Used to express the speaker's hope or desire that what is stated in the sentence will become a reality.

column1: 寿司が好きな人もいるし、嫌いな人もいる。
column2: There are people who like sushi and there are people who don't like sushi.
column3: N1も　V-plainし　N2もV Means: some do ~ and others do ~; sometimes ~ and sometimes ~; do ~ and ~ among other things, and more (pg 142 in とびら）

column1: この教科書は、会話も練習できるし、文化も学べます。
column2: With this textbook you can practice conversation and study culture among other things.
column3: N1も V-plain　し、N2も V  Means: do ~ and ~ among other things; sometimes ~ and sometimes ~; ~ and also ~; ~ and ~ as well; other meanings exist: pg 142 in とびら

column1: 寿司好きな人もいれば、嫌いな人もいます。
column2: There are people who like sushi and there are people who don't like sushi.
column3: N1も V-conditional, N2 も　V。 Means: some do ~ and others do ~; do ~ and ~ among other things; sometimes ~ and sometimes ~; there are times when ~ and times when ~; ~ and also ~; ~ and ~ as well. This sentence structure is used to present some members in a group, things in a category, actions someone takes, characteristics of something/someone, etc. among others. Although the form of the verb here is conditional, the meaning is NOT conditional in its usage.

column1: この教科書は、会話も練習できれば、文化も学べます。
column2: With this textbook you can practice conversation and study culture among other things.
column3: N1も V-conditional, N2 も　V。 Means: some do ~ and others do ~; do ~ and ~ among other things; sometimes ~ and sometimes ~; there are times when ~ and times when ~; ~ and also ~; ~ and ~ as well. This sentence structure is used to present some members in a group, things in a category, actions someone takes, characteristics of something/someone, etc. among others. Although the form of the verb here is conditional, the meaning is NOT conditional in its usage.

column1: このリゾートはきれいな海で泳ぐこともできれば、山にハイキングに行くこともできる。
column2: At this resort you can swim in an unpolluted ocean as well has hike in the mountains.
column3: N1も V-conditional, N2 も　V。 Means: some do ~ and others do ~; do ~ and ~ among other things; sometimes ~ and sometimes ~; there are times when ~ and times when ~; ~ and also ~; ~ and ~ as well. This sentence structure is used to present some members in a group, things in a category, actions someone takes, characteristics of something/someone, etc. among others. Although the form of the verb here is conditional, the meaning is NOT conditional in its usage.

column1: 田中先生の研究室には、百年以上前の辞書もあれば、最近の映画のDVDもある。
column2: In Professor Tanaka's office there are dictionaries from more than a hundred years ago as well as DVDs of recent films.
column3: N1も V-conditional, N2 も　V。 Means: some do ~ and others do ~; do ~ and ~ among other things; sometimes ~ and sometimes ~; there are times when ~ and times when ~; ~ and also ~; ~ and ~ as well. This sentence structure is used to present some members in a group, things in a category, actions someone takes, characteristics of something/someone, etc. among others. Although the form of the verb here is conditional, the meaning is NOT conditional in its usage.

column1: 漢字を勉強する時いつも、どうしてこんなにたくさん漢字があるのだろうかと思う。
column2: When I practice kanji, I always wonder why there are so many of them.
column3: Sの（だろう／でしょう）か  Means: I wonder ~ Indicates a self-addressed question which can either be a yes-no question or a wh- question.

column1: なぜ彼は私のことを愛してくれないのだろうか。私は彼がこんなに好きなのに。
column2: Why doesn't he love me back when I love him so much?
column3: Sの（だろう／でしょう）か  Means: I wonder ~ Indicates a self-addressed question which can either be a yes-no question or a wh- question.

column1: 田中さんは1年中咳をしている。熱もあるようだ。病院に行かなくて大丈夫なのだろうか。
column2: Mr. Tanaka has been coughing all day long. He also seems to have a fever. I wonder if he shouldn't go to the hospital?
column3: Sの（だろう／でしょう）か  Means: I wonder ~ Indicates a self-addressed question which can either be a yes-no question or a wh- question.

column1: A:　スミスさんは、将来日本の会社で働くのが夢なんだって。　　B:へー、スミスさんがそんな夢を持っているなんて、絶対知らなかった。
column2: A: They say Ms. Smith's dream is to work at a Japanese company in the future.    B: Really? I had no idea she had a dream like that.
column3: （そんな／あんな／こんな）N そんな／あんな： Means: that kind of ~; ~like that あんな： Means: this kind of ~; ~ like this  these words are synonymous with そういう、ああいう、こういう respectively and are a bit more colloquial than them.

column3: ~わけだ。 is used in 3 situations. For this one it is (1) when a speaker provides the reason for a previous statement. Means: The reason is that ~; It means that ~; That's why~; No wonder~; naturally

column3: S1. 「では／それでは」S2. Means: If that's the case; If so; In that case; Then; Well then  では is the abbreviated form of それでは which literally means "if that is the case" and それ refers to what was said in the previous sentence(s). では and それでは are used in *written or formal spoken* language.  In ordinary casual conversation, the contracted form それじゃ or じゃ is used. As it is here.

column1: はい。それでは、金曜日の先生の研究室にうかがいます。
column2: Yes. In that case, I will come to inquire at the teacher's office on friday.
column3: S1. 「では／それでは」S2. Means: If that's the case; If so; In that case; Then; Well then  では is the abbreviated form of それでは which literally means "if that is the case" and それ refers to what was said in the previous sentence(s). では and それでは are used in *written or formal spoken* language　(as it is here).  In ordinary casual conversation, the contracted form それじゃ or じゃ is used.

column3: S1. その上、S2. Means: on top of that; in addition (to that); what's more; besides; moreover  その上 is used when the speaker wants to emphasize an additional piece of information. S2 usually contains the particle も or まで。 as here.

column3: 〜くせに Means: Although~; in spite of the fact that~; and yet~ This conjunction is used when something commonly expected from information in the subordinate clause (i.e. the くせに phrase/clause) does not happen or is not the case. In most situations, くせに expresses the speaker's anger, frustration or disagreement. This emotion is not directed toward the speaker, but toward the hearer or 3rd person. When くせに is used, the subject of the main clause and that of the subordinate clause must be the same. If the subjects differ, you must use なのに、.

column3: S　(という）のは事実だ。 "It is {true/a fact that} ~"  Used when the speaker wants to claim that something is true or is a fact, or when he/she admits that something is true or a fact. The presence or absence of という does not change the meaning.

column1: 東京は物価が高いことだけでなく、土地も狭いので、暮らしにくいというのは事実だ。
column2: The fact is that Tokyo is a hard place to live in, not only because the prices are high there but also because the land is small (i.e. there are too many people for the land)
column3: S　(という）のは事実だ。 "It is {true/a fact that} ~"  Used when the speaker wants to claim that something is true or is a fact, or when he/she admits that something is true or a fact. The presence or absence of という does not change the meaning.

column1: 私が彼のことが好きだというのは事実だが、将来彼と結婚しようと思っているわけではない。

In different contexts, it can mark something one has interest in. Do not confuse with the use where に対して indicates two contrasting actions, states, situations, etc.

column1: 次の電車がすぐ来るから、急ぐことはありません。ゆっくり行きましょう。
column2: The next train will come soon, so we don't need to rush. Let's take our time.
column3: V-plain.non-past すること（は）ない "don't have to ~; don't need to ~; It's not necessary to ~; There is no need to ~" In casual conversation the は may drop.

column1: インターネットで注文すればいいから、店まで買いに行くことはないよ。
column2: Because we can just order it on the Internet, there's no need to go to the store to get it.
column3: V-plain.non-past すること（は）ない "don't have to ~; don't need to ~; It's not necessary to ~; There is no need to ~" In casual conversation the は may drop.

column2: You studied hard, so you shouldn't be surprised that you got a perfect score.
column3: V-plain.non-past すること（は）ない "don't have to ~; don't need to ~; It's not necessary to ~; There is no need to ~" In casual conversation the は may drop.

column1: 彼と別れてもがっかりすることないよ。もっといい人がすぐ見つかるから。
column2: You don't have to be down just because you broke up with your boyfriend. You'll meet someone much better in no time.
column3: V-plain.non-past すること（は）ない "don't have to ~; don't need to ~; It's not necessary to ~; There is no need to ~" In casual conversation the は may drop.

column1: スミスさんは、日本語が上手だ。なぜかというと、日本に長く住んでいたからだ。
column2: Mr. Smith is good at Japanese. As to why, it's because he lived in Japan for a long time.
column3: {どうして／なぜ} かというと 〜から {だ/です／etc.}  "The reason is (that) ~; Because ~" If the sentence starts with どうして／なぜ it must end with から　だ／です。

column1: 私は辛い食べ物が好きだから、どちらかというと日本語料理より、韓国料理の方が好きだ。
column2: I like spicy food, so if I had to pick, I'd say I like Korean food more than Japanese food.
column3: どちらかというと "if anything; rather; if I have to decide"  This is a set phrase.

column1: A:　今度のミーティングはいつですか。　B:　えっと、今度のミーティングは五日というと、あっ、来週の水曜日ですね。
column2: A: Where's the next meeting? B: Let's see, the next meeting is… here wo go, next Wednesday.
column3: {いつ／だれ／どのぐらい} かというと "to tell you when/who/etc.~ (it is ~)."  Question word + かというと literally means "if I were to tell you who/what/when/etc." In general this phrase is used to emphasize the information which follows or to delay providing the information in order to keep the hearer in suspense or to stall while recalling it.

column1: このコンピュータのメモリは、どのぐらいかというと、２GB ぐらいです。
column2: As for how much memory this computer has, it's around 2 GB.
column3: {いつ／だれ／どのぐらい} かというと "to tell you when/who/etc.~ (it is ~)."  Question word + かというと literally means "if I were to tell you who/what/when/etc." In general this phrase is used to emphasize the information which follows or to delay providing the information in order to keep the hearer in suspense or to stall while recalling it.

column1: 次に発表する人は、誰かというと、田中さんです。
column2: The next presenter is… um… it's Ms. Tanaka.
column3: {いつ／だれ／どのぐらい} かというと "to tell you when/who/etc.~ (it is ~)."  Question word + かというと literally means "if I were to tell you who/what/when/etc." In general this phrase is used to emphasize the information which follows or to delay providing the information in order to keep the hearer in suspense or to stall while recalling it.

column1: A：頭が痛いです。 B： それなら、すぐに寝た方がいいよ。
column2: A: My head aches. B: If that's the case, you should go to bed right away.
column3: それなら "If that's the case; If so"  それ meaning "that" refers to the speaker's previous statement of the statement which was just made by the hearer.

column1: A：今度、どこか美味しいレストランで食事したいと思っているんだけど。　B：ああ、それなら、新しくできた和食レストランに行ってみたら？なかなかおいしかったよ。
column2: A: I think I want to eat out at a restaurant with good food tonight. B: Oh, if that's so, why don't you try that new Japanese restaurant? It was pretty good.
column3: それなら "If that's the case; If so"  それ meaning "that" refers to the speaker's previous statement of the statement which was just made by the hearer.

column1: 両親は毎日のように、よく勉強していい大学に入りなさいと言います。それなら、私が勉強しているとき、弟や妹に静かにするように言ってほしいと思います。
column2: My parents tell me almost every day to study hard so I can get into a good university. If that's what they want, I want them to tell my little brother and sister to be quiet while I'm studying.
column3: それなら "If that's the case; If so"  それ meaning "that" refers to the speaker's previous statement of the statement which was just made by the hearer.

column1: 漢字が難しいと思っている学生は少なくない。
column2: Plenty of students think that kanji are difficult.
column3: N {は／が／も}　少なくない  "many; much; plenty of; not a few'  少なくない is a double negative meaning "many; much" and is commonly used in written language. It cannot modify nouns. For ex. 少なくない人 is a BAD expression.

column1: インタネットを通して、色々な情報を得ることが出来る。
column2: You can obtain various information via the internet.
column3: N を通して "through; via"  を通して indicates a medium (X) through which someone does something or something happens. X can be things, people, activities or actions.

column1: 昨夜から今朝にかけて、たくさん雨が降った。
column2: From last night to this morning it rained alot.
column3: N1 から N2 にかけて "from N1 to N2"  indicates a span of time or space and is used primarily in written language.

column1: ここから隣の町にかけて、スーパーやレストランが並んでいるので、道がとても混む。
column2: Supermarkets are lined up from here to the next town, so the street is very crowded.
column3: N1 から N2 にかけて "from N1 to N2"  indicates a span of time or space and is used primarily in written language.

column1: 今の気温は華氏 (fahrenheit) で50度だから、摂氏で言うと10度ぐらいだ。
column2: The temperature right now is 50 degrees Fahrenheit, so in terms of Celsius its about 10 degrees.
column3: "in terms of; in; according to; from the viewpoint of"  で言うと is used to restate something according to a different system or framework (e.g. a calendar, a measurement system, a language, a country's history)

column1: 各国の代表者が集めって、テロの犯罪について会議を開いた。
column2: The countries gathered each of their delegates and opened the session related to Terrorism.
column3: 各 + N "each ~; various"  A prefix which adds the meaning "each; various." When the referent of the noun after 各 is unknown, it means "various."

column1: ここには各先生のメールアドレスと、各セクションの教室の番号が書いてあります
column2: Written here are each teacher's mailing address and each section's classroom's number.
column3: 各 + N "each ~; various"  A prefix which adds the meaning "each; various." When the referent of the noun after 各 is unknown, it means "various."

column1: あのレストランは、安いばかりでなく、とてもおいしい。
column2: That restaurant is not only inexpensive, it is very delicious.
column3: S ばかりでなく This structure is similar to XだけでなくY(も). It is usually used in written language.

column1: 京都には日本内からばかりなく、世界中から観光客が来る。
column2: There are not only native Japanese in Kyoto, but sightseers from all over the world.
column3: N1(part) ばかりでなく N2(part) +(も） This structure is similar to XだけでなくY(も). It is usually used in written language.

column1: このさむらい風の人形は、いくらですか。
column2: How much is this doll that looks like a samurai?
column3: N1 風の N2 "~style; ~type; look like"  風 is a suffix and is added to nouns to make no-adjectives. X風 means "X style/type" or "looks like X"

column1: このドレスは着物風だ。
column2: This dress is kimono style.
column3: N風だ。 "~style; ~type; look like"  風 is a suffix and is added to nouns to make no-adjectives. X風 means "X style/type" or "looks like X"

column1: 言葉は時代と共に変化する。
column2: Words evolve along with the era.
column3: Nと共に "with; along with; as"  indicates that someone does something or that something happens with N.

column1: みんなが同時に話さないで、一人ずつ順番話して下さい。
column2: Don't all talk at the same time, talk one at a time, in turns, please.
column3: {Number +(counter)} +ずつ "per/a; at a time; each; (little) by (little)"  The number/amount X+ずつ indicates that someone does something (or something happens) with X as the unit.

column1: ホテルのビュッフェで色々な種類の料理をちょっとずつ食べてみた。
column2: Little by little I tried the various types of food at the hotel's buffet.
column3: non-specific amount expression + ずつ "per/a; at a time; each; (little) by (little)"  The number/amount X+ずつ indicates that someone does something (or something happens) with X as the unit.

column1: このゲームは子供から大人に至るまで、誰でも楽しめます。
column2: From children all the way to adults, anyone can enjoy this game.
column3: N1 から N2 に至まで "from N1 all the way through N2; from N1 to even N2."  This construction indicates a span of time or space and emphasizes the size of that span at the same time. It can also be used for other than spatial or temporal spans, as seen here. Primarily used in written language.

column1: 友達同士で話し合って下さい。
column2: Talk among your friends, please.
column3: N同士 {が／で／を}  Indicates that Ns do something together, that Ns do something to/for/against each other, or that someone puts Ns together in some way.

column1: 自分で出来ることば、自分ですべきだ。
column2: Things that you can do yourself, you ought to do yourself.
column3: V. plain.non-past.aff　べき {だ／じゃない／ではない／だった／じゃなかった／ではなかった}  "should; ought to"  The auxillary べき expresses the speaker's strong judgment that one should do something.  The form of する before べき can be either す or する, as in すべき or するべき。

column1: 空の様子からすると、夕方には雨になるようだ。
column2: Judging from the state of the sky, tonight it will be rain.
column3: Nからすると "judging from~"  Introduces the source or basis for the speaker's conjecture or judgment. The information can be of any sort including visual or  verbal.

column1: 思わぬ結果になって、びっくりしている。
column2: An unthought of result occurred, it gave us a shock.
column3: V-nai ぬ "not"  ぬ is a verb ending from classical Japanese and is equivalent to ない in meaning and form. In modern Japanese, it often appears in set phrases.

column1: 日本の国土は狭そうに思われているが、数字の上で見ると、そうでもない。
column2: Japan's national land is thought of as narrow, but if you look at it in terms of numbers, it isn't so.
column3: N のうえで "in terms of; from the viewpoint of ~; as far as ~ is concerned; according to ~"  Nの上で and N上 are used to indicate that the speaker's statement refers only to N.  Commonly used in written language.

column1: 翻訳の上での間違いが、お互いの国の間に誤解を生んでしまった。
column2: As far as the translation is concerned, it's mistakes birthed misunderstanding between the countries.
column3: N1 の上での N2  "in terms of; from the viewpoint of ~; as far as ~ is concerned; according to ~"  Nの上で and N上 are used to indicate that the speaker's statement refers only to N.  Commonly used in written language.

column1: 田中さんは、健康上の問題があって、仕事を辞めた。
column2: Tanaka, as far as health is concerned, has problems so he quit work.
column3: N1 上の N2  "in terms of; from the viewpoint of ~; as far as ~ is concerned; according to ~"  Nの上で and N上 are used to indicate that the speaker's statement refers only to N.  Commonly used in written language.

column1: 日本の歴史上、明治維新は大きい意味を持っている。
column2: According to Japanese history, the Meiji Restoration has a profound (big) meaning.
column3: N 上  "in terms of; from the viewpoint of ~; as far as ~ is concerned; according to ~"  Nの上で and N上 are used to indicate that the speaker's statement refers only to N.  Commonly used in written language.

column1: 奈良は京都と並んで、古い歴史のある町で、日本の首都だたこともある。
column2: Nara, just like Kyoto, is a city with a long history (old history) and was once Japan's capitol.
column3: N と並んで "as well as; just like"  Is used when introducing one or more examples to be compared to the subject of the sentence.   It is used primarily in written language.

column1: おそらく来年は、日本に行けるだろう。
column2: I'm supposing I probably will be able to go to Japan next year.
column3: おそらく〜だろう "probably"  おそらく means "probably" and usually occurs with the conjecture auxiliaries だろう or でしょう。

column1: 彼と私の考えはまったく同じだ。
column2: His and my thoughts are exactly the same!
column3: まったく {V/A/ANo/(の)N/Ano}  "totally; utterly; entirely; completely; extremely; absolutely; really"  used for emphasis in affirmative sentences. often used to express the speaker's emotion.   In negative sentences, it indicates complete negation. It is used with verbs (often in potential form) and i-adjectives in negative sentences. まったく〜（という）わけではない indicates partial negation.

column1: このレポートはまったくだめだ。
column2: This report is completely bad.
column3: まったく {V/A/ANo/(の)N/Ano}  "totally; utterly; entirely; completely; extremely; absolutely; really"  used for emphasis in affirmative sentences. often used to express the speaker's emotion.   In negative sentences, it indicates complete negation. It is used with verbs (often in potential form) and i-adjectives in negative sentences. まったく〜（という）わけではない indicates partial negation.

column1: このカレーは辛すぎて、まったく食べられない。
column2: This curry is too spicy, I can't eat it at all.
column3: まったく〜ない "not ~ at all; not ~ in the least"  used for emphasis in affirmative sentences. often used to express the speaker's emotion.   In negative sentences, it indicates complete negation. It is used with verbs (often in potential form) and i-adjectives in negative sentences. まったく〜（という）わけではない indicates partial negation.

column1: 納豆は嫌いだが、まったく食べられないというわけではない。
column2: I hate Natto, but it's not that I totally can't eat it.
column3: まったく〜（という）わけではない "It's not that ~ totally/completely/extremely/etc." used for emphasis in affirmative sentences. often used to express the speaker's emotion.   In negative sentences, it indicates complete negation. It is used with verbs (often in potential form) and i-adjectives in negative sentences. まったく〜（という）わけではない indicates partial negation.

column1: いったいあなたは何を考えてそんなことをしたんですか。
column2: What on earth were you thinking to do such a thing!?
column3: いったい QW  "(what, who, where, how, etc.) on earth"  いったい is an intensifier used with questions. It usually occurs immediately preceding the question word, but it may appear in other locations before the QW, as seen here.

column1: いったいいつ終わるのだろうか。
column2: When on earth will (this/it) end?
column3: いったい QW  "(what, who, where, how, etc.) on earth"  いったい is an intensifier used with questions. It usually occurs immediately preceding the question word, but it may appear in other locations before the QW.

column1: この絵はモネによって描かれたとされているが、絵の中にモネのサインは入っていない。
column2: It is believed that this painting was painted by Monet, but Monet's signature is not in the painting.
column3: S-plain　とされている "it is thought/believed/considered that~; ~ is considered/believed to ~"  This is used to introduce a commonly accepted idea or belief.

column1: 家に帰って、いつも第一にすることは、Eメールのチェックだ。
column2: When I go home, the thing I always do first is check my email.
column3: 第一 に V "first; first of all; to begin with; the first; the primary"

column1: 試験に合格できた第一の理由は、覚えた言葉や漢字が全部試験に出たことだ。
column2: The primary reason I passed the exam was that all the words and kanji I remembered were on it.
column3: 第一 のN "first; first of all; to begin with; the first; the primary"

column1: 彼女の第一印象は悪かったのに、なぜか私と彼女はとてもいい友達になった。
column2: Even though the first impression of her was bad, somehow she and I became good friends.
column3: 第一 N "first; first of all; to begin with; the first; the primary"

column1: 私のモットーは「健康が第一」です。
column2: My motto is "Health first!"
column3: N が第一 だ。 "first; first of all; to begin with; the first; the primary"

column1: この大学の図書館には、アジア経済に関する本がたくさんあります。
column2: In this university's library there are many books concerning Asian economics.
column3: N1 に関する N2 formal "with regard to; concerning; regarding; about; on; related to"

column1: 和紙の利用法に関して調べてみたら、とても面白いことがわかった。
column2: After researching about how to use Japanese paper, you will learn very interesting things.
column3: N に関して V formal "with regard to; concerning; regarding; about; on; related to"  について is similar in meaning to に関して, but is less formal and is used in both written and spoken language.

column1: コンピュータの知識に関しては、彼が一番だと思う。
column2: With regard to knowledge of computers, I think he is best.
column3: N に関して は S formal "with regard to; concerning; regarding; about; on; related to"  について is similar in meaning to に関して, but is less formal and is used in both written and spoken language.

column1: 現代人にとって、コンピュータのない生活は考えられないだろう。
column2: To the modern person, a lifestyle without the computer is probably inconceivable.
column3: N {は／なんて} 考えられない "unimaginable; inconceivable; unthinkable"

column1: 漢字が800も書けるようになるなんて、日本語の勉強を始めた時には考えられなかった。
column2: To become able to write as many as 800 kanji was unimaginable when I first started studying Japanese.
column3: S-plain {ということは／なんて} 考えられない "unimaginable, unthinkable, inconeivable"

column1: 将来は、自分の能力を生かすことが出来る会社で働きたい。
column2: In the future, I want to work at a company where I can make the most of my abilities.
column3: 生かす "make the most of; make the best use of; use effectively; maintain"  生かす means literally "to keep alive," but it is also used to mean "to make the most of one's ability, etc"

column1: 土の中から魚の骨や貝などが出てきたことから、ここは大昔海だったということが分かった。
column2: We understood that this place was a sea a long time ago from the fact that shells and fish bones came out of the earth here.
column3: ことから "because; from the fact that"  ことから is used to express a reason

column1: 早く辞書なしで新聞が読めるようになりたい。
column2: I want to become able to read a news paper quickly, without a dictionary.
column3: N なし で　V "without ~; with no ~"

column1: 今はもうコンピュータなしの生活は考えられない。
column2: At this time, life without a computer is unimaginable.
column3: N なし の　N "without ~; with no ~"

column1: ダイエット中だから、今日はデザートなしだ。
column2: I'm in the middle of dieting, so (I'll go with) no desert today.
column3: N なし だ。  "without ~; with no ~"

column1: 今年こそ日本に留学したいと思っている。
column2: I think that I will definitely study abroad in Japan this year.
column3: N こそ "the very ~; It is that~; in particular; precisely; definitely; only (when, by doing, etc~)"  こそ emphasizes the preceding word, phrase or clause. When こそ is used, the particles は、が and を drop.

column1: スタジアムに行って実際に見てこそ本当の面白さが分かるのだ。
column2: Only by going to the stadium and seeing it in real life can you understand the interest of it.
column3: V-te こそ  "the very ~; It is that~; in particular; precisely; definitely; only (when, by doing, etc~)"  こそ emphasizes the preceding word, phrase or clause. When こそ is used, the particles は、が and を drop.

column1: 大きい音に驚いて、ガムを飲み込んでしまった。
column2: Surprised by a loud sound, I gulped down (swallowed deeply) my gum.
column3: V−masu　込む "in; into; deeply; heavily; thoroughly; completely"  The compound verb base 込む can mean one of 4 things:  (A) Taking or putting something/someone into something {飲み込む}

column1: 昨日は久しぶりに会った友達と一晩中話し込んで、徹夜してしまった。
column2: Yesterday, I got deep into conversation with a friend I hadn't seen in a while and ended up pulling an all-nighter.
column3: V−masu　込む "in; into; deeply; heavily; thoroughly; completely"  The compound verb base 込む can mean one of 4 things: (c) being heavily involved in something {話し込む}

column1: その子は水に飛び込む気持ちにはどうしてもなれなかった。
column2: He could not bring himself to jump into the water.
column3: V−masu　込む "in; into; deeply; heavily; thoroughly; completely"  The compound verb base 込む can mean one of 4 things: (B) getting into something {飛び込む}

column1: 自分は絶対に正しいと思い込んでいる人とは、あまりはなしたくない。
column2: I don't really want to talk to people who are convinced that they are always right.
column3: V−masu　込む "in; into; deeply; heavily; thoroughly; completely"  The compound verb base 込む can mean one of 4 things: (D) doing something thoroughly and completely {思い込む}

column1: キムさんってさあ、フランス語がペラペラなんだけど、日本語も上手なんだってさ。
column2: About Kim, you know, she's good at French, but also good at Japanese, you know.
column3: phrase/clause/sentence さ(あ) "(you know)"  さ occurs after phrases, clauses, or sentences in very casual conversation. One function is to catch the hearer's attention, but it is also used as a filler with no meaning.

column1: 私が住んでいるアパートは、周りが静かなだけでなく安全でもあるので、学生に人気がある。
column2: As far as the apartment where I live, the surrounds are quiet and also safe, so it is popular with students.
column3: N／ANa でもある "be also"  X は Y でもある. OR X は Y でもあり、Z でもある。 Are used to introduce another property of X when X has more than one property.

column1: 今日は朝からずっと雨が降った。
column2: It rained all the way through today since morning.
column3: ずっと "all the time; all along; all the way; all through ~; throughout~; ever (since); never (since)"  ずっと means that a state or action is ongoing, from one point in time to another point in time (often the moment of speech)

column1: 今から2,3時間、図書館に勉強しに行ってきます。
column2: In 2-3 hours from now, I will go to the library to study.
column3: Number1, Number2 + Counter  "(2 or 3) days/times/etc.; (3,4) hours/cars/etc."  Two successive numbers are used to indicate an approximate number or amount

column1: 今のままだと、地球温暖化は止まらない。
column2: If things remain the same as now, earth's global warming will not stop.
column3: N  のままだ "remain the same as ~"  まま indicates that the state of X remains unchanged or that someone does something without changing the current state of X.

column1: あのまま日本に残っていたら、もっと日本語が上手になっただろう。
column2: After remaining in Japan in that way, you became more skillful with japanese, didn't you?
column3: DemAまま "remain the same as ~" まま indicates that the state of X remains unchanged or that someone does something without changing the current state of X.

column1: このお菓子は、冷たいまま食べるより、電子レンジで温めた方がおいしく食べられますよ。
column2: As for this confectionary, instead of eating it still cold, as it is, if you heat it in the microwave it'll be more delicious to eat.
column3: Aまま（で）V "V with ~; V while ~; V as (it is); V without ~"  まま indicates that the state of X remains unchanged or that someone does something without changing the current state of X.

column1: これはこのままにする。
column2: Leave this as it is.
column3: Xままにする。 "leave ~ as (it is)"  "remain the same as ~"  まま indicates that the state of X remains unchanged or that someone does something without changing the current state of X.

column1: 彼は２０代で会社を作り、３０代で、大金持ちになった。
column2: In his 20s he built a company, and in his 30s he became a very wealthy person.
column3: 10/20/30/etc.　＋ 代 "one's teens/twenties/ thirties/etc."  The suffix 代 is used with ten or its multiples to describe someone's approximate age.

column1: 1980年代の後半から1990年代の初めにかけての日本の経済は「バブル経済」と呼ばれている。
column2: Japan's economy from the last half of the 1980s to the beginning of the 1990s is called "bubble economy."
column3: 1900/1910/1920/etc. + 年代 "1990s/1910s/1920s/etc."  the suffix 代 is used with 10 or its multiples and 年 to refer to a certain decade.

column1: 日本では秋になると仕事の面接に行くスーツ姿の学生が増える。
column2: When it turns to fall in Japan, students wearing suits for going to job interviews increases.
column3: N　(の）姿 "in ~; wearing ~;  姿 means "appearance; figure". It is used to describe someone's  external appearance, i.e. someone's form or physical form or physical appearance; someone's appearance in certain clothing; or the ay someone appears when he/she is doing something.

column1: 母が病気で苦しむ姿を見て、私は将来医者になろうと心に決めた。
column2: Seeing the way my mother suffered from illness, I decided in my heart to become a doctor in the near future.
column3: V-plain.non-past 姿 "the way one V"   姿 means "appearance; figure". It is used to describe someone's  external appearance, i.e. someone's form or physical form or physical appearance; someone's appearance in certain clothing; or the ay someone appears when he/she is doing something.

column1: 今日は朝から、雨が降ってはやみ、降ってはやみしていて嫌な天気だ。
column2: From morning today, it rained and stopped and rained and stopped over and over again; it was nasty weather.
column3: V1-te　は V2 "V1 and V2 repeatedly/over and over again/many times/etc."  The construction of VteはV is used when a set of actions is repeated over a period of time. It can be said once, or repeated, as here.

column1: 子供の頃は、毎年夏休みになると、家族と海に泳ぎに行ったものだ。
column2: During my childhood, ever summer break my family and I would go to swim in the sea.
column3: V-plain.non-past ものだ "used to ~; would"  V-plain.past ものだ is used to describe in a nostalgic fashion what someone did or what happened in the past

column1: 毎日日本語で話すようにしていると、だんだん上手に話せるようになりますよ。
column2: If you are trying to speak in Japanese every day, you will gradually become able to speak skillfully.
column3: だんだn  "gradually; little by little; bit by bit"  だんだん is used to indicate that a state changes gradually. Thus, it often occurs with ~ていく; 〜てくる；〜くなる；〜になる；〜ようになる

column1: 暖かくなるにつれて、雪が溶け、木が緑になっていく。
column2: With it becoming warm, the snow will melt and the trees will turn green.
column3: V-non-past.aff につれて "as ~; with ~"  Xにつれて indicates that omething takes place as X occurs. X can be either a verb or the stem of a suru-V.

column1: 技術の進歩につれて、私達の生活は便利になった。
column2: With the progress of technology our lives became more convenient.
column3: Nにつれて "as ~; with ~"  Xにつれて indicates that omething takes place as X occurs. X can be either a verb or the stem of a suru-V.

column1: 今日中にこのレポートを書き上げてしまわなければならない。
column2: Before today is over I must finish writing up this report.
column3: 書き上げる transitive "to write out or down; to finish writing"  Affixed to the end of masu-stems of verbs, 上げる forms compound verbs, adding meanings such as "finish something up," "upward," or "to a great extent." The meaning is determined by the preceeding verb.

column1: この荷物は重すぎて誰も持ち上げることは出来ない。
column2: This luggage is too heavy, nobody can lift it up.
column3: 持ち上げる transitive "1: to elevate; to raise; to lift up; 2: to flatter; to extol; to praise to the sky"  Affixed to the end of masu-stems of verbs, 上げる forms compound verbs, adding meanings such as "finish something up," "upward," or "to a great extent." The meaning is determined by the preceeding verb.

column1: 日本語を勉強している学生が、自分達で日本語のブログサイトを立ち上げた。
column2: The Japanese language students started up a Japanese blog site all by themselves.
column3: 立ち上げる （V-masu 上げる） transitive "to start (something); to start up; to boot (a computer)"  Affixed to the masu-stems of verbs, 上げる forms compound verbs, adding meanings such as "finish something up," "upward" or "to a great extent." the meaning is determined by the preceding verb.

column1: 泥棒はコンビニの店員を縛り上げて、レジのお金を盗んで行った。
column2: The thief tied up the convenience store clerk, then went and stole money from the register.
column3: 縛り上げる （V-masu 上げる） transitive ”to bind (tie) up”  Affixed to the masu-stems of verbs, 上げる forms compound verbs, adding meanings such as "finish something up," "upward" or "to a great extent." the meaning is determined by the preceding verb.

column1: この岩を磨き上げてください。
column2: Please polish up this rock.
column3: 磨き上げる (V-masu 上げる） transitive "to polish up; to shine up"  Affixed to the masu-stems of verbs, 上げる forms compound verbs, adding meanings such as "finish something up," "upward" or "to a great extent." the meaning is determined by the preceding verb.

column1: 2行目から10行目まで、読み上げた。
column2: I read loud and clearly lines 2-10.
column3: 読み上げる (V-masu 上げる) transitive "to read out loud (and clearly); to call a roll"  Affixed to the masu-stems of verbs, 上げる forms compound verbs, adding meanings such as "finish something up," "upward" or "to a great extent." the meaning is determined by the preceding verb.

column1: 会社への行きがけに銀行によって、お金をおろして行こう。
column2: On our way to the company, let's stop at (by means of) the bank and withdraw money.
column3: V-masu がけに "on one's way"  がけに is used with the masu-stem of motion verbs like 行く、来る、and 帰る to mean "on one's way."

column1: 日本に行ったら 英語は使わないでなるべく日本語だけで生活するつもりだ。
column2: If I go to Japan, I plan on not using English and speaking just Japanese to live.
column3: N だけで "just N (is fine/enough/etc.)  N/Vだけで is used to express the idea that X or just doing X is fine or good enough or that one can do something just with X or by doing X.

column1: この植木は２週間に一度水をやるだけでいいですよ。
column2: Just watering this plant once in two weeks time is enough.
column3: {V-plain.non-past/N} だけで {いい／十分だ／etc.}  "just with ~; just by V-ing (is fine/enough/etc.)  N/Vだけで is used to express the idea that X or just doing X is fine or good enough or that one can do something just with X or by doing X.

column1: 「飲むだけでやせられる薬」などという広告は信じない方がいいですよ。
column2: It's better not to believe advertisements that say things like "just by taking this medicine, you'll lose weight!"
column3: V1-plain だけで V2  "just with ~; just by V-ing (is fine/enough/etc.)  N/Vだけで is used to express the idea that X or just doing X is fine or good enough or that one can do something just with X or by doing X.

column1: この読み物は、あまりにも漢字が多すぎて、何か書いてあるのかまったく理解できない。
column2: In this reading material there are way too many kanji, I can't understand what's written here at all.
column3: あまりに（も） "too; excessively; so"  あまりに（も） indicates that the degree of something is excessively high. It is commonly used in formal language.

column1: 隣の家のパーテイがあまりにうるさかったので、警察を連絡した。
column2: The next door neighbor's party was excessively loud, so I contacted the police.
column3: あまりに（も）{A/Anaだ}  "too; excessively; so"  あまりに（も） indicates that the degree of something is excessively high. It is commonly used in formal language.

column1: あまりに便利な生活は、人間を駄目にすると思う。
column2: I think an excessively convenient lifestyle is not good for a person.
column3: あまりに（も）{Adv/ANa/A-stem く}  "too; excessively; so"  あまりに（も） indicates that the degree of something is excessively high. It is commonly used in formal language.

column1: 漢字を覚えるにはフラッシュカードを作るのが一番です。
column2: (It is my opinion that) in order to be able to memorize kanji, making flashcards is the best.
column3: V-plain.non-past.aff には "to; in order to; for; for the purpose of; when"  には　indicates purpose in general statements (often stating the speaker's judgement about an action in terms of its effectiveness, convenience, necessity, etc.). には can also mean "when" (=時には). Verbs or nouns can precede には.   Note that when ために is used, the predicate in the main clause describes an action. Such that: Xには Y, where Y is a judgment and never an action  XためにY, where Y is an action and never a judgement.  AND, XためにはY, where Y is a judgment, never an action

column1: 海外旅行には、このスーツケースを持って行くと便利ですよ。
column2: When you travel overseas, to take this suitcase with you will be convenient.
column3: N (of a VN, or direct object of する) には  "to; in order to; for; for the purpose of; when"  には　indicates purpose in general statements (often stating the speaker's judgement about an action in terms of its effectiveness, convenience, necessity, etc.). には can also mean "when" (=時には). Verbs or nouns can precede には.   Note that when ために is used, the predicate in the main clause describes an action. Such that: Xには Y, where Y is a judgment and never an action  XためにY, where Y is an action and never a judgement.  AND, XためにはY, where Y is a judgment, never an action

column1: 先生の説明を聞いて、この言葉の意味はだいたい分かったけれど、まだ上手に使えない。
column2: Upon hearing the teacher's explanation, I mostly understood the meaning of this word, but I still can't use it skillfully.
column3: だいたいV "mostly V; nearly V; almost V"  だいたい means "most, almost, nearly (all), approximate." The meaning changes depending on what it modifies.

column1: この大学では、だいたいの学生がアルバイトをしている。
column2: At this university, most students have part time jobs.
column3: だいたいの N  "most N; almost all N; approximate N; rough N"   だいたい means "most, almost, nearly (all), approximate." The meaning changes depending on what it modifies.

column1: だいたいの数は分かりますが、正確な数は調べてみないと分かりません。
column2: I know the approximate number, but if I don't look it up I don't know the accurate number.
column3: だいたい　number/amount "approximately number/amount"  だいたい means "most;almost; nearly(all); approximate." The meaning changes depending on what だいたい modifies.

column1: ７時から大学ホールにおいて学生会議が行います。
column2: The student meeting will occur in the University Hall from 7:00.
column3: N1 において V "in;at;on;during"  The compound particle における indicate the place or time of an action, event, or state. The pre-verbal form is において.  Both are used only in formal language.

column1: アジアにおける歴史に関する問題は、解決が難しそうです。
column2: Problems related to history in asia are seemingly difficult to find a resolution for.
column3: N1 における N2  "in;at;on;during"  The compound particle における indicate the place or time of an action, event, or state. The pre-verbal form is において.  Both are used only in formal language.

column1: 暑いのは好きではないが、寒いのもまた苦手だ。
column2: I don't like heat, but I also dislike the cold.
column3: もまた "as well; also; too"  In this usage もまた means the same as も; however it is more emphatic and formal than も.

column1: なんだ、まだ宿題終わってないの。早くしないと、授業がはじまっちゃうよ。
column2: oh, you haven't finished your homework yet?! If you don't finish quickly, class will start (before you're done)!
column3: なんだ "oh!"  The literal meaning of なんだ is "What is X?" However it can also be used to express the speaker's slight surprise。 Used only in very casual conversation.

column1: ほら、これ、見て。リリーが子犬の時の写真。かわいいねえ。
column2: Come on, look at this! It's a picture from when Lily was a puppy. Cute, huh?
column3: ほら "Look!; See?; Come on!"  The interjection ほら can be used to draw the hearer's attention to something. Only used in very casual conversation.

column1: 盲導犬などのサービスドッグを除いて、病院には犬を連れて入ってはいけません。
column2: With the exception of sevice dog s, like guide dogs, you cannot bring a dog with you into the hospital.
column3: N を除いて "except (for); with the exception of ~; but ~"  除く means "to remove; get rid of." を除いて is used as a compound particle meaning "except."

column1: 留学中、沖縄を除く日本全国各地を友達と一緒に旅行した。
column2: While studying abroad, I traveled together with my friend to every place in all of Japan except Okinawa.
column3: N1 を除く N2 "except (for); with the exception of ~; but ~"  除く means "to remove; get rid of." を除いて is used as a compound particle meaning "except."

column1: 昭和25年頃、すなわち 1950年頃の日本は、戦争が終わったすぐ後で、みんな貧乏だった。
column2: Immediately after the war ended in Japan, around the Showa year 25, that is around 1950, everyone was destitute.
column3: NP1/S1, すなわち NP2/S2 "that is; i.e.; namely"  すなわち

column1: 受付の仕事は一応私達がやることになっています。
column2: It has been decided that will will do reception desk work for the time being.
column3: 一応 "for the time being; for now; tentatively; although not perfectly; sort of; just in case"  In this sentence the use means "for the time being"  一応 is used when an action/state is tentative or not quite complete, perfect or satisfactory. It is also used when an action is taken as a precaution.

column1: コンピュータがフリーズする問題は一応解決したけれど、まだ、メールが文字化けするという問題が残っている。
column2: The problem with the computer freezing was tentatively resolved, but the problem of garbled letters appearing in emails remains.
column3: 一応 "for the time being; for now; tentatively; although not perfectly; sort of; just in case"  In this sentence the use means "tentatively"  一応 is used when an action/state is tentative or not quite complete, perfect or satisfactory. It is also used when an action is taken as a precaution.

column1: レポートは一応書き上げたけれど、英語のスペルチェックがまだだ。
column2: Although not perfectly, the paper is completed; all that remains is English spell check.
column3: 一応 "for the time being; for now; tentatively; although not perfectly; sort of; just in case"  In this sentence the use means "although not perfectly"  一応 is used when an action/state is tentative or not quite complete, perfect or satisfactory. It is also used when an action is taken as a precaution.

column1: 作文はワープロで書いてもいいはずだが、一応、先生に聞いてみよう。
column2: It should be ok to write the report in Word Pro, but just in case, I'll try asking the teacher.
column3: 一応 "for the time being; for now; tentatively; although not perfectly; sort of; just in case"  In this sentence the use means "just in case"  一応 is used when an action/state is tentative or not quite complete, perfect or satisfactory. It is also used when an action is taken as a precaution.

column1: 日本でのインターンシップの経験は、私の人生を大きく左右するだろう。
column2: I wonder if the experience of an internship in Japan will will have a big influence on my life.
column3: N1 を N2 左右する "influence; govern"  左右する is most commonly used in written language.

column1: 今年の冬は、一月、二月共、あまり寒くなった。
column2: Winter this year got pretty cold in both January and February.
column3: N1,N2 共（に） "Both N1 and N2"  The colloquial form is N1もN2も.

column1: インターネットの時代に入って、人々の買物の仕方が変わった。
column2: Since entering the age of the internet, the way people shop has changed.
column3: N (time period) に {入り/入って (から)} "since N began; after N began"  N に入る literally means "to enter N," but when N is a noun indicating a time period, the phrase means "N begins." The most common form is N に入り or N に入って（から), meaning "since/after N began."

column1: 梅雨に入ってから、晴れの日がまったくなくて湿度が高く、気持ちが悪い。
column2: Since the rainy season began, there's been absolutely no sunny days, the humidity has been high, and it feel gross.
column3: N (time period) に {入り/入って (から)} "since N began; after N began"  N に入る literally means "to enter N," but when N is a noun indicating a time period, the phrase means "N begins." The most common form is N に入り or N に入って（から), meaning "since/after N began."

column1: 江戸時代に入り、和歌より俳句の方が楽しまれるようになった。
column2: After the Edo period began, haiku came to be enjoyed more than Waka.
column3: N (time period) に {入り/入って (から)} "since N began; after N began"  N に入る literally means "to enter N," but when N is a noun indicating a time period, the phrase means "N begins." The most common form is N に入り or N に入って（から), meaning "since/after N began."

column1: 地球の未来を考えたとき、何よりもまず初めに地球温暖化が問題にされるべきだ。
column2: When the Earth's future is thought of, it should be global warming which is brought up as an issue first before all other things.
column3: N/NP が問題に {される／なる} "X becomes an issue; X is brought up as an issue; X is questioned; X is called into question."  X を 問題にする means "to bring X up as an issue" or "to question X." This phrase is often used in the passive form Xが問題にされる. Xが問題になる is also common. The meaning is the same as that of the passive version.

column1: 私の母は、未だに携帯電話を持たずに生活している。
column2: My mother is still living her life without owning a cell phone.
column3: 未だに "still; (not ~) yet"  indicates that someone of something is in the same state as he/she/it was some time ago. This form is primarily used in written language. In spoken language まだ is used.

column1: リサーチを通して、私達がいかにエネルギーを無駄に使っているかを知った。
column2: Via research, we came to know how much energy was used wastefully.
column3: いかに〜か "how; how much; in what way"  This structure occurs as an embedded interrogative sentence, where いかに means "how (much)" or "in what way".   This structure is commonly used in written language.

column1: 母の料理がいかにおいしいかは、言葉では説明できない。
column2: I can't explain with words just how delicious my mother's cooking is.
column3: いかに〜か "how; how much; in what way"  This structure occurs as an embedded interrogative sentence, where いかに means "how (much)" or "in what way".   This structure is commonly used in written language.

column1: この問題をいかに解決すべきか、みんなで話し合わなくては鳴らない。
column2: (as for) in what way you ought to solve this problem, you must talk amongst each other (to figure it out).
column3: いかに〜か "how; how much; in what way"  This structure occurs as an embedded interrogative sentence, where いかに means "how (much)" or "in what way".   This structure is commonly used in written language.

column1: この論文はすばらしいと思う。しかしながら、賛成できない点もいくつかある。
column2: I think this thesis is amazing, however there are several points which I cannot agree with.
column3: S1. しかしながら S2. "however, but"  しかしながら is a disjunctive conjunction and appears only in sentence-initial position. It is a highly formal expression and is used typically in written language.

column1: このカレーはかなり辛いけれど、食べられないことはない。
column2: This curry is considerably spicy, but not to the degree that I can't eat it.
column3: かなり "considerably; rather; quite; fairly; pretty; quite a lot;   Indicates that the degree of something is not extremely high, but is higher than average.

column1: ピアノ、お上手ですね。いつ始められたんですか。
column2: You are skilled at piano. When did you start?
column3: る-verbs: V-masu + られる  Passive forms of verbs are used to indicate politeness when the speaker refers to the actions of the hearer or someone to whom the speaker wants to show deference. The auxilliary verb おられる is less polite than いらっしゃる。

column1: どんなアパートを借りるかは、家賃次第だ。
column2: The kind of apartment I will rent, will depend on the rent.
column3: N次第だ "depend on N"  When 次第 is affixed to nouns, it means "depend on."

column1: 漢字の勉強は覚え方次第で大変じゃなくなりますよ。
column2: Depending on how you memorize, your difficulties will disappear.
column3: N次第で "depending on N"  When 次第 is affixed to nouns, it means "depend on."

column1: 日本人だから漢字をよく知っているとは限らない。
column2: It's not necessarily the case that because you are Japanese you know kanji well.
column3: 〜とは限らない "not necessarily~; not always ~; it's not necessarily the case that~"  Xとは限らない means "it's not necessarily the case that X."  だ before とは is optional.

column1: 自分で、部屋は、毎日ちゃんと掃除して、きちんと片付けておきなさいよ。
column2: Properly clean the room everyday, yourself, and tidy up properly.
column3: ちゃんと；きちんと "neatly; tidily; properly; adequately; in good order; regularly; without fail"  ちゃんと and きちんと both indicate that someone does something neatly, properly, regularly, or without fail (i.e. in the way it is supposed to be done).  ちゃんと is more colloquial than きちんと。

column1: 日本語を勉強しているんだから、少なくとも一度は日本に行ってみたいと思っている。
column2: Since I am studying Japanese, I think I would like to go to Japan at least once.
column3: 少なくとも Number (+Counter)  少なくとも means "at least." It can be used with a noun  or number (optionally followed by a counter). When は follows a number (+counter), it emphasizes the number.

column1: 人に何かしてもらったら、少なくともお礼は言った方がいい。
column2: If someone does something for you, you should at least thank them.
column3: 少なくとも N (は）  少なくとも means "at least." It can be used with a noun or number. When used with a noun, は often follows the noun (or the particle after the noun), indicating that the noun is under focus.

column1: 海に行きたい人もいれば、山に行きたい人もいて、旅行の計画が全然決まらない。
column2: With some people wanting to go the ocean and others wanting to go the mountains, vacation plans won't be settled like this.
column3: N1 も V-cond, N2 も V "some do ~ and others do ~; do ~ and ~ among other things; sometimes ~ and sometimes ~; there are times when ~ and times when ~; ~ and also ~; ~ and ~ as well"  This structure is used to present actions or states (usually 2) as examples of possible or past actions/states. In many cases the actions/states are contrastive ones.

column1: 人生は考え方次第で、楽しくもなれば、苦しくも鳴る。
column2: Life, depending on how you think, can become fun, and it can also become agonizing.
column3: A-stem くも V-cond ば, 〜も "some do ~ and others do ~; do ~ and ~ among other things; sometimes ~ and sometimes ~; there are times when ~ and times when ~; ~ and also ~; ~ and ~ as well"  This structure is used to present actions or states (usually 2) as examples of possible or past actions/states. In many cases the actions/states are contrastive ones.

column1: この仕事は危険でもあれば大変でもある。しかし、誰かがやらなければならないのだ。
column2: This work is sometimes dangerous and sometimes difficult. But somebody has to do it.

column1: 一週間のうち、三日はアルバイトに行きます。
column2: 3 days a week I go to my part time job.
column3: N のうち(で) "in; of; among"  Xのうち(で）is used to indicate the total entity (X) when presenting a part or portion of X.

column1: 一週間の旅行のうち、三日間は東京に、後（の）四日間は京都に行く予定だ。
column2: Of the week of travel, 3 days will be spent in Tokyo, the remaining 4 days are arranged to be spent in Kyoto.
column3: 後（の）Number (+ counter) "the remaining ~; the remainder of ~; the rest of ~"  This use of 後 should be distinguished from 後 in the following example, where 後 means "~more." In this use, の cannot occur after 後.  このプロジェクトには後三人必要だ。

column1: これは私の物です。でも、後の物は全部ルームメートの物です。

column3: 後のN  "the remaining ~; the remainder of ~; the rest of ~"  This use of 後 should be distinguished from 後 in the following example, where 後 means "~more." In this use, の cannot occur after 後.  このプロジェクトには後三人必要だ。

The phrases are used to indicate that the speaker is unable to control his psychological/physiological reactions or bear a sensation or an external situation.　しかたがない and しようがない are interchangeable.  This use is different from the following example, where the しかたがない means "it cannot be helped; there's nothing one can do." お金がないのだから、留学できないのはしかたがない。

column3: 何から何まで "all; anything and everything; all kinds" 何から何まで means "all" and is more emphatic than 全部, すべて、or みんな. 何から何まで can be used with 全部、みんな、and　すべて。

column1: あの仕事は、立ちっばなしの仕事だから、疲れるに違いない。
column2: That work keeps you standing, so (he) must be worn out.
column3: V-masu　っばなしの　N "keep V-ing; leave"  This is used when someone or something keeps doing X or someone did X but did not finish the action properly.   As in this case, Vっばなし is often used to describe an undesirable situation, but this is not always the case.  Not used in formal language.
